So if we take a look now at this idea of Max Payne, let's talk about this. What is it? Well, in a nutshell, it's this right here. It's when there's an options expiration coming up, it's the market force where price tends to move towards the strike where the greatest value of options in that cycle would expire worthless. So there's a couple of assumptions that this has that market makers are the opposite side of these trades net sellers and they're hedging their positions. That's an important assumption and I agree with the assumption is broadly true. This also assumes that market makers then are incentivized to manipulate the stock such that this would happen. And that also is a viable estimation. Because when options expire in the money, a market maker has some work to do because into expiration, they need to hold the shares for what's going to expire in the money so that they can then deliver options that expire in the money and are exercised. That means that they have to hold shares. It increases their risk profile. They would much prefer options to expire worthless. So, yep, that also checks out. Now, there is a natural behaviour that is not just from manipulating stock, the stock price, but also from the natural practice of hedging that moves price a bit. And it's important to know that again, I think it's important to be as objective as possible. If we look at things and
